review_title: The job was interesting, but demands a lot out of an individual
job_title: Digital Media Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: I got to have experiences at this job I will likely never experience anywhere else. There was a decent number of benefits, including tuition remission and earning paid time off. There was also plenty of networking opportunities with professionals in my field. The field is pretty close knit across all universities, and provides a good opportunity to meet nice people.
cons: I worked at least 6 days a week every week while school was in session and was expected to be on call 24/7. Even on approved days off requests over the weekend in the summer, I was still called and asked to do work remote. During the school year, the usual routine was to work on campus, come home and continue to work until I went to bed. Work would quickly pile up and frazzle management, and often times I would not be supported or given guidance to help remedy the situation I was put in. The department I worked in was a not the most organized and could definitely be described as dysfunctional. Sometimes, asking for help would stress the people who told me I could reach out to them if I needed anything and the situation would become much more stressful and dysfunctional. On numerous occasions, I've been asked to assignments that I wasn't qualified for, or would require me to postpone work on projects that I was already working on. This would then lead to a cycle of making compromises that upper management wouldn't like despite them contributing to the reasons you're in that situation.

review_title: Keeping employees as contractual to avoid giving any benefits
pros: I was essential so I continued working throughout the pandemic
cons: I am contactual with zero possibility for my role to become regular. That means limited health benefits and no 401K. They don't even pay me enough money so that I can start my own retirement account. I have been told that every 3 years your position is evaluated by the state, and no previous person in this position has been made regular. Why would any continue working for an organization that promotes zero loyalty? Every year or every other year they have to hire a new person for this position. How much time and money is wasted looking for and training a new person?

review_title: A strong university with strong nepotism
pros:
-Great benefits (state employment)
-Flexibility in job and work schedule
-Great, nice people (typically in the middle management / budding leadership groups)
cons:
-Low pay / unbalanced pay for positions (see Baltimore Sun state salary database for specific records)
-High profile divisions have a lot of micromanagement
-Favoritism (personnel, as well as project/division)

The university carries with it an exceptional burden on its shoulders to constantly prove itself. This isn't necessarily a bad thing; and should lead to innovation to gain ground in the market.

However, due to decades of leadership built on the promotion of friends and focused on commitment to the "mission" or cause of the organization over direct, relatable work experience for the jobs/tasks, the university's progress has stalled.

Change will happen soon at the top, leading to systemic change across all organizational units. Until that time, I'd hesitate to make this place more than a pitstop on your career pathway.

review_title: Great institution, but due for some growing pains
pros:
Great people, overall, who care. The institution has an excellent reputation with undergraduate teaching and research. I stand by this. Fantastic leadership academically, overall.

Freeman's leadership and connections/respect externally are a driving force behind this mid-sized institution's accolades and exceptional programs. He has created an environment that values education, inclusiveness, and support for students from all backgrounds to succeed.
cons:
Divisional level leadership is very much hit or miss. Ironically, if you took the years of service of the VPs and Deans across the institution and added them together, it would be three times the age of the institution. Why is this important? Because, if a single leader has been in a position for 30 years, there is an innate ability to adopt status-quo and mediocrity.

This institution suffers from stagnant leadership, which will become increasingly apparent when Dr. Hrabowski leaves.

Note: compensation for non-director level positions is mediocre. Benefits are part of the State system, so they are quite good. As always, tuition remission is a great benefit to full-time non-contingent employees.

- Good work environment

review_title: Good place to work and study
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: A good place to work and study
cons: As if it doesn't have any disadvantages

pros: Great university with excellent PR & marketing of their students & professors accomplishments. Top rated school for many years & President Hrabowski is an amazing leader & gets things done. A lot of new facilities on campus. Overall a great school to attend, but maybe not one of the best to work at.
cons: HR: lengthy processes & mandatory abhorrent orientations for new hires, including waiting 4 weeks to get your first paycheck?! State institution that suffers furlow days, salary cuts, hiring freezes & more monetary injustice to employees who are not being paid much to begin with. Campus is constantly under construction, but employees salaries were being cut – doesn't make much sense?

pros: Great people, everyone is helpful and there is lots of training if needed. The students are very smart and I enjoy working with them. Lots of things to do such as lectures, concerts, movies, recitals, sporting events and plays if you want to take advantage of them. Many are free or reduced for students and staff.  Great benefits and off between Christmas and New Years Day always, spring break of three days. Computer replacement programs insures you are never working with a dinosaur computer. Great place to work.
cons: Salaries and raises are at the mercy of the State of Maryland system.  There has been furloughs in past years. Management tries to be fair and subject those with the highest salaries to the most furlough days. Parking can be a bear at peak times during the semester.

pros: There is some schedule flexibility (depending on which category you are in), good environment to teach with nice facilities.
cons: It is State government, so there is a lot of bureaucracy. Like most higher education places, the politics of faculty vs staff are exhausting. I think there are lots of bad decisions made with staffing, some core services experience too much turnover (like the Registrar). I think that salaries are ok and you should be alright IF you get along with your department, but this is something the University has struggled for years with. Tenure process is ridiculously easy (embarrassing for an honors university), Everyone gets it unless you are just a terrible candidate.

pros: Great benefits and a lot of PTO. Freeman is a fantastic leader. You can tell that he really cares about UMBC and the students.
cons: Big HUGE communication fail between leadership and staff. At/below the VP level, misconduct is always being swept under the rug. If you are bullied or harassed? HR will tell you to find a job somewhere else. Morale is HORRIBLE and upper management has no idea because they take middle management's word for it that everything is fine in their departments.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros:
The department I work at is very friendly and not competitive at all. You can actually discuss your work with others and get good feedback. 
UMBC in general is a good school, small and with friendly and helpful people. Highly accepting of international students and diversity.
cons: Since the school is small it is not very well known. The department I work at currently faces money problems and so in terms of working environment it has become very stringent and less enjoyable. Research seems to be taking a turn towards the business side which is completely out of the idea of what research is all about.

pros: Even though the job itself wasn't that interesting (calling alumni to ask for donations) the people I worked with and the boss really made the time fun. The boss really put together a team of people who worked together well, and went to many lengths to help those struggling succeed. It seems most of the jobs on campus understand needed to do less hours around finals time as well.
cons: I really have a difficult time coming up with cons. It wasn't the most interesting job in the world, but I worked with people I liked, got to work on homework when people weren't picking up the phone, and got paid a lot. Maybe the ability to work more than 9 hours a week would be nice, but as a part time job I don't think it was necessary.

review_title: Great place to start your carrer
pros: Great benefits including free tuition for employees and their family members. My coworkers were wonderful to work with.  My supervisors were supportive and encouraging.  I learned a lot, and was provided with a lot of training (however, you have to be open to being assigned new duties and responsibilities with out immediate rewards). Lots of flexibility. I was able to tele-work one day a week.
cons: Alike many other government institutions, the work can become repetitive, and it can be hard to move up.  Pay is low for the area.

pros: My supervisor asks about my availability every semester, so it never interferes with my time for school or other extracurricular activities.
cons: So many people are employed there that it's difficult to work more than  6 hours a week without constantly asking to cover the shifts of coworkers.  There is a lot of expectations and responsibility for someone who is getting paid minimum wage.

review_title: Good stepping stone if you want to step out...
job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant in Catonsville, MD
pros: Tuition remission is a good tradeoff since you won't be paid well.  In other words, don't expect private industry salary from a state-run university.   Nevertheless, feel free to take advantage of tuition remission benefits, but read the fine print very closely to make sure you won't be charged taxes on your tuition remission benefit (unless you can afford receiving a partial pay check for several weeks at a time).
cons: See pros...there's always a flip-side to everything.

pros: The working environment at UMBC Library so comfortable and so organised, that I never felt any troubles and if by chancce there were any I had three angels to my rescue. It was the most wonderful time of my life working for the A & R Dept of Library,
cons: As such there is no downside of my work. Only thing that my work includes was a little much of physical work. Other than that, evrything was a breeze. And their is one thing that you have to be punctual to keep up with the work flow.

pros: UMBC is a community of people who care -- above all, that is its best trait. I know my colleagues care about me both professionally and personally. Additionally, my department  encourages people to take creative risks and try new things. There is some room for growth if you're willing to step out of your comfort zone and take on new challenges.
cons: As a state institution, budget is always a challenge. My department also struggles, occasionally, to maintain a realistic portfolio -- we're not good at saying no. It comes from a good place -- we want to help everyone we can -- but it can lead to employee burnout.

pros:
- Health / Leave benefits
- Flexible hours
- You can take classes*
- Teaching positions available
- Windows in most offices
- Yard crew making the campus look great
cons:
- Classes are outdated (when you do sign up)*
- Quite a few complacent instructors (who will not talk to you if you are not signed up for their class)*
- Parking (they make you pay to park at work-- Yes, that is right: They cut your pay to give you a parking spot ultimately to pay for the student bus service.  A bus service that is underfunded and people with cars don't need the bus service.  -- NOTE:  Use the free parking at research park drive which is a 15 minute walk)
- Little incentive for improvement.  Starting in 2005, people have been at the same pay level for 11 years.  They did a hiring freeze, which means that if you change positions or colleges you still get the same pay level, even if the new position is more specialized.  Not much incentive there to work more.
- Watch out for those people who have no incentive to do work, and just push the buck.  They put needless / useless paperwork in your way which turns out to be outdated / not needed.  Word of advice: Get a second opinion before filling out any form.

review_title: Kind-hearted people who made common errors when attributing graphic design feedback
pros: I discovered I am able to work with a variety of personalities on tight deadlines, and I was given a great opportunity to learn those skills. In fact, I found out that my co-workers were creative in finding ways of improving their surroundings.
cons: I found out that university bureaucracy does not allow for the most creative expression. In other words, the university limited my ability by creative rigid and inflexible style guide requirements.

pros:
- Low cost or free health insurance
- Supportive environment for learning, research, and teaching
- great graduate student association for helping students succeed and thrive
- Nice academic environment
cons:
- Low salary
- No retirement savings opportunities
- Very infrequent Cost of living adjustments (only one in my tenure)
- Only 10 vacation days
- Only 10 sick days

pros: Co-workers are awesome. There's a lot of freedom in designing one's teaching curriculum. Classrooms are being updated to include the latest technologies, which make it more pleasant for those of us who like to travel into a work area with as few extra materials as possible.
cons: Pay is about average for government work. Parking can be costly or difficult to find because the school keeps taking out parking lots to put in new buildings. Scheduling classrooms to teach in can be extremely disheartening.

pros: Excellent education reputation and well deserved.  Happy students, well run school.  President Hrabowski is smart and committed to the school.
cons: Parking is always a problem for both staff and students.  Lay offs and unpaid furlough days always hanging in the air as possibilities at the will of the state budget.

review_title: No Respect and Low pay in return for Excellent Adjunct Teaching
pros: The classes are filled and students are wonderful; library services are wonderful. To find respect and good service, you have to look beyond the department you are teaching in and rely on this respect from the wider campus community and offices.
cons: The pay is too low and no benefits; No respect from the department chair and its full time faculty

review_title: UMBC is a very supportive and innovative environment.
pros: UMBC is a very DIY campus, there are lots opportunities to try new things and grow in your positions.
cons: While it is easy to try new things, authority is very decentralized and it is difficult to get new projects elevated and systematized across the whole campus.

pros: Mostly supportive environment, staff care about each other, very low turnover amongst employees, some really amazing colleagues to learn from
cons: because of the low turnover it takes longer than it should to get things changed, hard to move up as well, old school approach to things

pros: I've greatly enjoyed working as a tour guide within UMBC Admissions. The job is flexible and the office is a wonderful community.
cons: If you are one that likes to work a set schedule or guaranteed hours, this job might be a bit inconvenient for you. Tour schedules vary from week to week.

pros: An amazing group of faculty members and students under one roof.
cons: Please see comments below. Under Advice to Management

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Catonsville, MD
pros: It's easy work and the pay is decent depending on the professor you work under. It's very flexible during the semester.
cons: You get paid through the University of Maryland system and they are very disorganized so it took me close to two months to get my first paycheck.

pros:
Comfortable atmosphere
Amicable peers
Little supervision, work at your own pace / around your own schedule
cons: Some information was not made clear as a newcomer

pros: You learn a lot. Teaching really strengthens your subject knowledge. Great faculty.
cons: Many of the graduate students accepted into the program are incompetent in teaching. The stronger teaching assistants have to make up for the slack. In addition, the students weaker at teaching end up with easier teaching assignments (e.g. grading). Doesn't really seem to resolve the major problem that they struggle with teaching and most plan to be professors one day...

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: compact campus; relatively less pressure; for the most part, you pressure comes from your advisor. If you got a pushing one, you will work a lot, otherwise you are on your own.
cons: not much help you can get for your career from alumni etc.. Most senior professors are hard to find since they are too busy. In most cases you don't get to work in a team but on yourself.

pros: Was an ok place to work. I worked with two professors at UMBC. A pretty decent place to work if you are a student there already.
cons: It can get boring sometimes especially if you are working with a professor who doesn't really explain their project clearly to you.

pros: The hours at the Design and Print shop are very flexible. Also, the designers and animators work together in one room, so it's rather collaborative. Although the students are working at minimum wage, it's an excellent application of what they are taught in classes.
cons: The personnel is frequently changing, resulting in some confusion for newcomers and clients during transitions. However, it is something that cannot be helped.

pros: Sometimes we were traveling with students and were able to see places
cons:
- ELI have awful management that make you work extra without providing clear info about benefits

- Not providing clear picture of business benefits and potential growth

- No guidance

review_title: Medium-size school, great place to work and study.
pros: It locates in a very great neighborhood, and has very convenient acess to downtown and airport. People who work here are friendly and willing to help. Great place to work and study.
cons: Public schools, budget is totally depending on the MD state. Some of the departments need new research directions or hire new professors who are in different field.

pros: Nice surroundings, tuition remission, lots of  vacation and holiday paid time off,  telework available, free downloadable software, nice food court, gym use for staff too.
cons: Support staff have little opportunities to career advance, top Administrative staff get raises; however support staff told no monies available for raises. Causes huge gap in pay between top Administrative and bottom support staff.

review_title: You will learn everything you need as a professional.
pros: You will wear many hats due to the nature of the non-profit businesses.
cons: Need to be motivated and have strong leadership skills and communication skills. You will also need to find a work-life balance as soon as possible, as this is a salaried job and some aspects of the job require travel and weekend or evening work.

review_title: Postdoctoral Fellow - Really depends on supervisor
pros: Good University in the Maryland System.  Everything is standard for the State of Maryland, so not much to say here.
cons: The work day-to-day life really depends on the supervisor.  I was not very lucky with that and had some issues with the immediate boss. Everything worked out in the end but the contract was short.

pros:
Friendly quiet environment
One can follow his/her dreams
Has a very good President
An active dynamic with a bright future school
cons:
Does not have a good student support
Does not have enough strong networking
The training is OK but does not have enough facilities

pros: Lots of friendly staff and great mentors! Great location and great pay and benefits. I really enjoy working here and look forward to what the future has to bring in the department
cons: Main concern is that the food is quite expensive in the area. Another con is that the building is quite old so the bathrooms aren’t that nice l.

pros: People for the most part are nice, campus is pretty, easy to get to.
cons: Paying for parking, below industry rate salary, pension is not a good retirement option as you are force to stay for 10 years for vesting.  Opt for the 403B instead.  Many people are here for far too long and promotion opportunities are infrequent.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Caring staff and faculty who really value the opinions of others. They are most often very flexible when it comes to scheduling, and go out of their way to accommodate you.
cons: I had such a great experience there as a student and as a teaching assistant that it is hard to think of any!

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: UMBC is a research-based college and has a very good environment to promote creativity and teamwork. Professors are knowledgeable and nice.
cons: No enough parking space seems always be an issue at UMBC. Too few choices of dining places may be another drawback of the campus.

pros: Excellent and supportive staff who genuinely want to see personal and professional growth in their colleagues. Always open to questions and suggestions.
cons: Some of the bureaucratic structures are inefficient. Pay not that great for all the work you are expected to do. Certain offices give off a "cliquey" kind of atmosphere.

pros: you are a part of a well led organization. it is a state run, job security is huge if you contribute, you see the results of your work.
cons: Only con is that that the private sector tends to pay better. i loved working here, growing here and being educated at a quickly growing school.

job_title: Manager of Keith R Porter Imaging Facility in Baltimore, MD
pros: The students at UMBC are among the best in the country.
cons: No support from anyone. University wanted a money making shop with no interest in education of students.

pros: You can gain administrative work experience. This job also helps in gaining soft skills. I got to learn the transfer services process for credits
cons: Need to handle pressure. Sometimes you need to listen to people's rage and handle their anger as supervisors are not willing to come upfront

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good employee benefits under the Maryland state system.
cons: Grant-funding limited and research is defined by a clear statement of work with deliverables so that other basic exploratory research may not be considered. This, of course is grant specific and does not apply to all areas of research existing in the university community.

review_title: Best work/school place to be Keeping improving sports team - they are best
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: All great, nothing bad about UMBC... they are the best Keeping improving sports team - they are best
cons: No Cons.. everything is amazing Keeping improving sports team - they are best

pros:
- most professors are fun to work with
- get paid while earning degree
- other graduate students are great
- my advisor was awesome!
cons:
- too many class requirements even after admission to candidacy 
- stipends could be higher in certain departments
- with respect to TA duties, sometimes have difficult students

review_title: Couldn't have asked for a better team
pros:
- supervisors care about you as a person
- supervisors care about your future and offer optional opportunities to further education
- atmosphere is fun but also pushes you to do your best
cons: - payroll is slow and will be two weeks late, always

review_title: you have to be a full time student, in a graduate program
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: an easy and healthy environment. Huge responsibility with the teaching and grading
cons: Parking is very difficult. you have to park with students which is near impossible to find parking in the first 20 minutes.

pros: Good faculty with numerous opportunities for professional growth and continuous learning through workshops.   High quality leadership from the President on down.
cons: No cons, as this is a great place to work.

review_title: Good place to work...but does have some cons.
pros:
*Collegial environment, 
*Work-life balance is encouraged here
*Strategically located near other major institutions of higher learning
*COLA is affordable very near the university
cons:
*Food desert!
*Parking sucks during the year
*Lack of resources for high quality STEM research
*Low pay for the field

job_title: Summer Conference Manager in Frederick, MD
pros: Great place to meet new people and make friends with people my age passionate about learning. Over all a great experience
cons: Long hours were sometimes difficult. Many long nights worked and being on call could mean no sleep for the night

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Halethorpe, MD
pros: UMBC is close to NASA GSFC, which makes the university more attractable. Ongoing collaboration with GSFC with several departments makes it a challenging and frontier in research.
cons: Course work as a graduate student is comparatively easy.

pros: Good atmosphere. Boss understands when you cant work because of own coursework takes precedent. Keeps you up to date on your intro levelclass knowledge through the tutoring that you do.
cons: I have no cons to say.

pros: Desk staff work typically asks very little of workers and allows them to be fairly flexible with their scheduling.
cons: Mandatory training and professional development meetings do nothing for workers and seem to only exist to appear professional.

job_title: Corporate Quality Manager in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Flexible hours
Can do homework while you work
Part of financial aid package for students who need to work while in school
cons:
Hours depend on school schedule - limited
No regular employee benefits
No opportunity to advance (pay )

pros: Very friendly, great place to learn office culture, ethics and a right place to learn all the required office assistant skills, and flexible.
cons: Can get boring, but with the right people around you'll see yourself doing really well.

pros: A great place to work at, as makes you grow both individually and professionally; great teamwork based place!
cons: I didn't find any, as you mainly work with students; great staff as well!

pros: management staff is nice and helpful. benefits are unbeatble. compensation is not the greatest but decent for univeristity
cons: promotion is a little slow. It requires at least a six year of service to apply for a promotion.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Healthy stipend along with tuition remission. Very satisfying job.
cons: No cons as such. It's a peasant experience. Job is in campus and pays for insurance as well.

pros: Great benefits, conducive to graduate coursework, and wonderful people
cons: A lot of abbreviations and acronyms in the language to ask for clarification in the beginning. Once you get a hang of this, you will be fine.

pros: Great people from the top down. Faculty have a great deal of support. Teaching gives me a sense of purpose.
cons: Faculty earn on average $10,000 less than faculty at College Park.

pros: Small campus, easy to get a hold of people. Very nice area.
cons: Not a lot of options in research and classes since the school is still growing

review_title: Good overall quality, but there is room for improvement
pros: A good place to learn new things and meet new friends from different countries and cultures
cons: Salary is not very satisfying. Requires more investment to provide more state-of-the-art equipment

review_title: Great first time or on campus job
pros: Learn about how to get hired and get good office experience
cons: Often doesn't have enough work for their student workers, few hours available

review_title: Working as a Teaching Assistant is great!
pros: The pay is good for the work that I am doing. It is also very low stress.
cons: Nothing that I can think of right now.

pros: As a statistics TA, helping students who may only ever take one stat course understand and appreciate the material has been gratifying.
cons: Not really any cons. Some classes are less interesting than others.

pros: I was able to sharpen my java skills working with students of all levels
cons: I was stretched a little thin, I tutored for 6 sections of classes with only one other tutor

pros: very friendly atmosphere, get to work with students, work-life balance is good, good benefits
